title: Cannon and marble - energy of marble-cannon system

This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

Students launch marbles of mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> horizontally from a toy cannon of mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="uppercase M sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is always greater than <math alttext="lowercase m sub m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. Each time a marble is launched, the cannon slides backward before coming to rest. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the cannon and the ground is <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu). For each launch, the students use a new marble with a different mass launched at the same speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> relative to the ground. The students record the distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> the cannon slides backward for each launch.

(a) Without manipulating equations, briefly describe what happens to the distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that the cannon slides backward as students increase the mass of the marble. Explain your reasoning.

This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

Students launch marbles of mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> horizontally from a toy cannon of mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="uppercase M sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is always greater than <math alttext="lowercase m sub m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. Each time a marble is launched, the cannon slides backward before coming to rest. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the cannon and the ground is <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu). For each launch, the students use a new marble with a different mass launched at the same speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> relative to the ground. The students record the distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> the cannon slides backward for each launch.

(a) Without manipulating equations, briefly describe what happens to the distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that the cannon slides backward as students increase the mass of the marble. Explain your reasoning.

(b) Students find the following equation on the Internet to describe the distance <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that the cannon slides backward: <math alttext="x equals, the fraction with numerator lowercase m sub lowercase m, end sub, squared, times v squared, and denominator 2 g times mu, times uppercase M sub C, end sub, squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><msup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>g</mi><mi>μ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Whether or not the equation is correct, is it consistent with your prediction in part (a)? Briefly justify your answer.
(c) Without manipulating or stating equations, briefly describe whether it would take more work to stop the marble or to stop the cannon after the marble has been launched. Justify your answer.

(d) Students correctly derive the following equation relating the work <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> done on an object initially at rest, the momentum <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the object, and the mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the object: <math alttext="W equals, the fraction p squared over 2 times lowercase m, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is this equation consistent with your description in part (c)? Justify your answer.

Students then discuss the mechanical energy of the marble-cannon system during the short time interval in which the marble is accelerated inside the cannon and make the following claims:
Student 1: The cannon is pushing the marble forward, and the marble is pushing back with equal and opposite force. Since the work done by the cannon cancels out the work done by the marble, the mechanical energy of the system is constant.
Student 2: The mechanical energy of the system increases while the marble is being accelerated. The marble gains kinetic energy to the right, and the cannon gains an equal amount of kinetic energy to the left.
(e) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 1’s statement are correct, if either? If neither phrase is correct, write “none.”
(f) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 1’s statement are incorrect, if either? If neither phrase is incorrect, write “none.”
(g) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 2’s statement are correct, if either? If neither phrase is correct, write “none.”
(h) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 2’s statement are incorrect, if either? If neither phrase is incorrect, write “none.”

The graph above shows the horizontal component of the velocity of the marble (dashed line) and the cannon (solid line) relative to the ground. Before time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> the marble-cannon system is at rest. At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> the marble begins accelerating within the cannon, and at time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> the marble leaves the cannon.

(i) Provide three pieces of evidence that together explain why the magnitude of the rate of change of the cannon’s velocity is less than the magnitude of the rate of change of the marble’s velocity during the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.
